title: Inconsistent VAR is losing credibility... the PGMOL need to go back to basics
text:
I believe the time has now arrived for the PGMOL to arrange a taskforce with players, coaches, media and supporters and listen to ways in which VAR can be improved, because in its current format it is losing credibility.

VAR is here to stay, we need to accept that, but it has been undermined this season by inconsistency and by the PGMOL setting the bar far too high when it comes to determining a clear and obvious error.

They need to go back to basics and, if the VAR official believes the referee has made an error, he should immediately recommend a pitchside review in the monitor available. I find it staggering this facility is not being used.

I was astonished when VAR did not instruct a penalty should be awarded to Gerard Deulofeu

I'm sure the referees are happy with the system because they are not being blamed — all of the focus is on VAR. That is why we need to give referees the final call and, if a review of a decision is necessary, let them take another look.

At Spurs on Saturday, Jan Vertonghen tripped Watford's Gerard Deulofeu in the area and my immediate thought was: 'Penalty.' I was astonished when VAR did not intervene and instruct that a penalty should be awarded. The defender made no contact with the ball and tripped his opponent. At the very least the referee should have been told to take a second look.

Mike Riley, head of the PGMOL, said recently there had been four VAR errors this season. I, like many others, believe there have been far more, especially when it comes to fouls in the penalty area being missed. We cannot have mistakes when the VAR official has every angle available to him.

VAR is here to stay, we need to accept that, but it has been undermined by inconsistency

However, I am not surprised that no penalty appeal has been overturned by VAR this season.

Now that could be because the bar for intervention is set too high, or a VAR official does not want to upset his mate who is the referee.

Either way, it needs urgent review. Incidents like the big screen at Tottenham incorrectly showing 'No Goal' after the review for Dele Alli's goal do not help. Alli's equaliser was correctly allowed to stand — the ball hit shoulder, not arm.
